job_title: Financial Aid Advisor in Chandler, AZ
pros: Great people, training provided, salary is appropriate for work load, positive work environment
cons: still working through transition to new ownership. Needs better communication between management and staff. Promotions depend to much on politics.

pros: * hard working employees * dedicated and committed * good pay
cons: * management turnover * for profit education

pros: free college while working fulltime
cons: bad management lack of entry pay and slimy

pros: Working here was really helpful at the moment.
cons: It was difficult finding long term work.

pros: The starting salary was decent.

pros: Didn’t have much to do but starting pay was $14 hr in 2016, not bad to just sit at a desk.
cons: The company was going down hill when i started and ultimately they filed for bankruptcy & sold. People were let go but this was after I moved on.

pros: Company parties, some staff are really good at what they do
cons: Long hours, pay is terrible for non-managers

pros: Coworkers, great atmosphere, great health insurance
cons: I don’t have any. I enjoyed my time there

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Salary and benefits met a livable wage and allowed for reasonable healthcare and time off.
cons: Intense expectations that sometimes boiled over into a stressful work environment.

review_title: Would not recommend to a friend
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Denver, CO
pros: Some of the best people I have ever worked with.
cons: Pay, culture. Managers were unethical

pros: Great Co-Workers and Team Leaders
cons: Company was going downhill fast and no one could help it

pros: Argosy University entered into federal receivership on January 18, 2019 and its schools closed on March 9, 2019.
cons: Management Tuition Operations Opportunities for Advancement

pros: Good colleagues in the university
cons: Workload was unrealistic for allotted time

job_title: Student Support Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: They are once a good school
cons: This school was shut down by IDES

review_title: Incredibly Unethical and Prioritizes Financial Gain Over Student Needs
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: The university offers opportunities for students who would not have chances elsewhere, but I would strongly advise any students out there to attend a community college first.
cons:
-Inconsistent directions and improper/incomplete training.
-Company policies were unclear.
-Minute-by-minute micromanaging along with hourly check-ins with my supervisor.
-Management set unrealistic expectations and regularly compared my job goals with others rather than setting goals with me personally.
-Management regularly discriminated against students of color and would make exceptions for other students that were not used for minority students.
-Management would also regularly make off-handed remarks and jokes about minority students' names or vernaculars.
-Management regularly held private meetings with other employees in an "inner circle" who would not otherwise have been able to attend them based on job description. This included representatives from HR which made reaching out Human Resources challenging.
-Rather than addressing issues directly with individuals and teaching, management would regularly go around myself and others to take matters into their own hands.
-The workplace was full of gossip and rumor; this extended to the most senior people on campus who would regularly discuss other employee performance openly.
-Management discouraged any social engagement in the workplace and if anyone was "wasting time" they would be reprimanded either verbally or given a warning.
-Students had zero to no resources on campus and frequently retracted from the program because of it. Those on the staff were then blamed for a shrinking student body.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Orange, CA
pros: Was the experience that got me interested in the field of education.
cons: Taught me what not to do as a counselor and recruiter.

job_title: Non Teaching, Administration Position in Eagan, MN
pros: Not many - the hours were easy with no pressure to work weekends, be in early or stay late. Easy going that way.  Some nice people.
cons:
Highly unorganizied and inefficient.  Horrible communication.  Awful payroll practices at the campus level - borderline incompetent.  EDMC regional and corporate in Pittsburg, which manages/controls critical details, clearly does not value employees in any way - noncompetive pay, poor and expensive beneifts, horrific benefits communication, little to no management training, nonexistant communication.  Constant change of policy and procedure in an organization that is driven by policy and procedure.
I had an employment experience that was unethical and just not the right way to treat anyone.  A series of incompetent leadership decisions.  No communication or true leadership, possible outright deception and misleading discussions early in the employment relationship.  I can't tell you that this was wide spread, but it did come from the highest position on campus and involved EDMC leadership.

job_title: Assistant Professor in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Here and there, there are a few good people.  A small minority of students were prepared for graduate school.  Most students were ill-suited (other than having access to Federal Student loans) for school
cons: Most everything.  Constant turnover.  Ill-thoughtout knee-jerk programming.  To call it a degree mill would be a compliment.  Only criteria for acceptance is a pulse, access to Federal student loans, or a credit card (pulse, optional).  No strategic direction.  Horrible execution.  Run by for-profit (vulture capital) management.  Education is an occasional by-product.  Continual lawsuits from shareholders, students, and federal government.  Most recently resulting in a $95.5-million legal payout to the Federal government for fraudulent recruitment.  In the end, the degree means nothing.  Many employers would read no further than that an applicant got a degree at Argosy and move on to the next application in the pile.  On top of all of this, the new Chancellor is a demon-driven tyrant.  There are two kinds of faculty and staff, those looking for another job or those unable to be hired anywhere else.  There is one kind of student, a victim in line for a degree of negative value and huge debt.  Tic-tock.  It is only a matter of time.

pros: Friendly staff and decent benefits. Hours were fairly predictable (i.e., no extra hours, or weekends) and therefore allowed for life outside of work.
cons: High stress and burnout. Some days better than others.A times it appeared that there were conflicting directives to employees, which lead to a sense of fear and insecurity. We were expected to "sell" prospective students on the benefits of attending Argosy, DC (which is actually located in Arlington, VA) at "any cost". Thus, if our recruitment numbers did not meet our sales goals, we were lectured about potential consequences. The position very quickly became one of fear of reprisal, job insecurity, high stress, and burnout. To say that our recruitment tactics to prospective students was disingenuous is an understatement. I feel a tremendous amount of guilt about the students that I helped recruit.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Decent paycheck. That’s all I can think of.
cons:
I’m assuming these other positive  reviews are written by the marketing department at Argosy. Very stressful environment with high turnover. They care more about the numbers compared to the student experience. Let’s be honest, this isn’t a real university position. It’s all sales!  The demographic of students they attempt to bring in is quite disturbing. They sell a dream to low income students and in the meantime, charge them $67k for a BA degree. 

No chance for advancement. Micromanaged constantly. The hire ups, Director , president, only care about their jobs and could care less about any of the other staff. I saw several admission reps get fired after missing unrealistic plans. They might need to find a new director because something isn’t right. I was happy to quit before it happened to me. Oh yeah, going non profit won’t secure anything.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Eagan, MN
pros:
Benefits were good after the standard 90 days
Decent job for the 20-something looking for a cheap education
cons:
No 401K match
No flex-time
Weak leads (admissions)
"Free" education is taxed
Too many reps calling from the same pool of candidates
Company is financially unstable
No advancement opportunities

review_title: Believe it or Not, It's a Nice Place to Work
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Arlington, VA
pros:
-Loved the staff 
-Very clean campus
-Did I mention staff
-Good amount of training
cons:
-Sometimes unrealistic expectations 
-Financial aid office members are often time very rude and do not help students at initial contact

review_title: Think twice before getting sucked in just because they're non profit
pros: The pay is decent and the employees are mostly great people. The director is awesome - so no one is sure why he tolerates managers who are baffoons.
cons: The managers are, indeed, baffoons (except for one - good job, Jess.) Leadership here makes you feel like you're in preschool. Stop talking down to us, stop condescending us, stop setting ludicrous expectations that cannot possibly be met. Put DOWN your damn cell phone and actually listen to your team. Grow the hell up and learn to motivate, not demoralize.

pros: Made some good friends along the way
cons: Little to no training that was irrelevant to the actual tasks performed. Literally locked in a room 8 hours a day on a computer for a week then thrown into a sales position (Admissions).  Very little direction. No substantive follow-up training. Clueless management. Senior director bailed before layoffs. Ambiguous policies. Zero marketing as per President’s beliefs that it wasn’t useful so never any quality leads. Not sure what he even did for us.. Very cold leads. Most leads called were many years old or they were tricked into thinking they were inquiring about a job. All about numbers. Pay raise freeze. No 401k match. No college reimbursement. Terrible medical. Benefits average at best, behind many other employers.

review_title: All awesome but the sudden ending!
job_title: Admissions Representative in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: You work with incredible co-workers everyday; the programs and resulting degrees are legit/excellent; best/most fulfilling job I ever had.
cons: Third-party call monitoring can end in your termination based on THEIR interpretation of what was said.  I had no infractions before getting my first; no chance to correct or defend what was actually said-just terminated.

pros: The newest campus desired to offer opportunities to applicants who might not get into other graduate programs.  The campus hired excellent faculty, interesting and diverse students, ability to develop one's own syllabus and teaching style, lots of ability to interact with students.
cons: The campus was driving the car while building it.  The campus president pushed large numbers of admissions to get his bonuses knowing many students were unprepared for such a diificult educational process.  The higher up management disallowed the individual campus to decide when it was ready to apply for APA approval.

review_title: The Pros and Cons of Argosy University
pros: Free tuition!  If you work there for over a year you can enroll in any of their programs for free.
cons:
Being one of 18 corporately owned campuses makes it difficult to get problems solved.  

It is a growing University that is struggling to break away from the "degree mill" persona.   In the meantime most of the departments (academic, administrative, etc) struggle to keep employees from being over worked and underpaid.

job_title: Admissions Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Excellent benefits package, with reasonable time off accommodations. The compensation is fairly decent and the location is beautiful. Work schedule is nice schedule with alternating Saturdays among team and there are plenty of training opportunities for employees.
cons: High stress for employees to achieve somewhat unrealistic goals and not all management is open or receptive to ideas on how to improve and change. Those who do present any opposition are met with negative consequences.  Advancement seems to be more on who you know and not who the most qualified is.

job_title: Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros:
-Amazing and fun coworkers.
-Tuition Discount (pretty much free with exception of taxes)
-Nice location and buildings
-Good Pay
cons:
-Good amount of vacation days but hard to use them with so many school start dates
-High pressure salesy environment. 
-Upper management is only concerned about numbers with little regard to students
-up and down job security
-admissions representatives are given more and more duties such that they do what other departments are being paid for like finance and retention

pros: Amazing Bennefits as well as amazing co-workers. Yep- that's pretty much it.
cons: telemarketing job. Managers are always on a power trip. Everything but an admissions representative, sales job (selling school). Repeatedly calling individuals who told another AR to put them on the do not call list. Almost all of the people you talk to just want job so they can pay bills, NOT take out student loans they will never be able to pay back. The practicality of half of the students getting a degree is horrible. I'm not sure how this "institution" is accreted. Classes are so simple and such a joke.

review_title: Completely worst place that I have ever worked for!!
pros: The only pro was having a decent salary, but it was absolutely not worth the misery and craziness.
cons:
* Inconsistent practices and policies
* Favoritism is evident
* No support from management
* No support from Human Resources
* Employees afraid to speak up due to repercussions.
* Management does not lead by example.
* Coaching from Manager was non-impactful and meaningless. 
* Leads are garbage. They have no marketing plan or campaign. Company solely relies on Facebook and recommendations to obtain leads.
* Database management systems are not effective and completely ancient. Poor functionality.
* They manage with fear instead of respect.

review_title: Some opportunities, but bureaucratic and highly political
pros: They have quite a bit of training and development content for employees, if you choose to take advantage of them.  Compensation can be good if you are at the Executive Committee level or higher at a campus.
cons: They are in a significant retraction mode and probably won't recover.  Very high stress level for most employees except those at the top, whether campus or HQ.  They'll suck the life right out of you, if you allow them.

review_title: Extemely challenging...presenting a product all other universities have at a much higher cost
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Good pay and benefits as compared to other schools
cons: too numbers driven...management doesn't understand that basis of sales diffculties here is that the price is just too high during bad economic times.  When other private universities were lowering tuition, Argosy University had the "balls" to increase its tuition.  We offer a good product, but not the best product, so why do we charge more than everyone else??

pros: Working in Higher Education is great!  Some of the programs are actually quite decent.  The Seattle Campus location is really nice.  Coworkers were friendly, smart and supportive.
cons: It's a for-profit University, what more do I say?  It's all about recruiting students and making money there...which is a shame because a lot of the students who come to a school like this don't really have a lot of other options.  Employees are pressured more to recruit and retain students, than to actually help teach.

review_title: Has its issues, but not a bad place for instructors to work
pros: The working conditions were good - they made an effort to orient new P/T instructors.  They also seemed to appreciate instructors.  The compensation was quite competitive.  They also had profit sharing options even for P/T instructors.
cons: At the time they seemed to be catching up with instructional technology.  Like many online or private for profit universities, their advising and admissions staff seemed underpaid and a bit overwhelmed.

pros:
Great Pay
Day's duties vary often
Great benefits
PTO and Holidays
Room for growth
cons:
Impossible Goals
Pressure on workers to "sell" the school to prospect students who are not ready
Too often there are changes to regulations, curriculum, and makes the job atmosphere unsteady

review_title: A for-profit IHE that values instructors with real-world knowledge and experience
pros: The students were great and the instructors knowledgeable. Class times were convenient and the level of discourse raised my thinking. The work required to earn a degree is rigorous, but worth it.
cons: The online component can sometimes be heavy on papers and "busy work." The sacrifice of face-to-face interaction among students and the instructor has to be weighed against the convenience of attending online.

review_title: I had a great supervisor, overall it was a nice learning experience.
pros: Most of the staff was very educated and friendly while I worked there.  I had a nice work station as well and the students were for the most part very nice.
cons: The president/VPAA were both subpar in my mind, did not have a lot of direction.  The senior managment was all over the place as well, no direction for staff.

pros:
Helping students succeed academically and seeing that translate into career success. 
Awesome co-workers and management.
University culture is the healthiest I have seen in any corporate environment.
Decent healthcare options. 
28 Days of vacation during first year and increases  year over year.
cons:
In the process of transitioning to a non-profit, which means job stability and benefits may greatly change. 
Pay is lower than the national average given the positions.

job_title: Admissions Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: Faculty are amazing. The majority of the student body are amazing. These two factors and the renewed focus on graduate psychology are why I have stuck around this long.
cons: Argosy is owned by the for-profit company EDMC. Nothing good has happened for Argosy since that happened. Hopefully this will be ending soon before they bring the downfall of the university.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions (ADA) in Denver, CO
pros: Supportive manager and encouragement to move forward with your personal educational goals. When people listen to the reach achievements of your efforts, it pays off in the end.
cons: No growth potential from this position. Online teachers are not on the same page as the faculty or adjunct teachers. There is a lot of turnover from this position.

review_title: C areer Services and Community Development Representativ
job_title: Career Services Specialist in Pago Pago, AS
pros: Great customer service and computer knowledge.  My education backs up my various skills that I have that can assist in situations when in need.  I love to assist people to make things better and to decipher what a person needs in case of the lack of words.  If I can help, it is a good deed for me for that day and many more days to come.
cons: Speak only English and Samoan,

job_title: Senior Admissions Representative in Pittsburgh, PA
pros:
-Very strong TEAM atmosphere.  
-Leadership cares about employees and their growth and development.  
-Competitive Salary and Great Holiday/PTO package.
-Recently Transitioned to Non-Profit, under new ownership!
cons:
-Like most companies, it takes time really get ahead and advance (be patient). 
-Hours can be long (9-6-with an hour lunch), but lots of opportunity for Overtime.

pros: As long as you meet your goals on enrollment, persistence, financial clearance, it was a nice place to work. Felt sorry for those who missed a start goal or 2.....
cons: Managers did not coach effectively. Sessions were rushed, just a means of pushing the required paperwork to show they did call coachings.  Speaking with co-workers was a far better means to get advice or different techniques to improve the calls.

review_title: Repressed memories from my time working here
pros: The only pro was that I worked with friends and met some decent people.
cons:
Cold calling people and encouraging them to go to school no matter what 

Accepting students on any grounds, even if you do not have proof of graduation, GED, etc. 

Had to get certain # of students every "semester" 

Encouraged to convince people to go to school even if they are wary

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: Many of the admissions staff actually care about the success of the students.
cons: The organization as a whole does not utilize the knowledge of their staff that have first hand interaction with the students. Management are high paid mouth pieces of upper management with no leadership skills or ethical stance. They do not support their staff and displays open favoritism.

job_title: Senior Director of Admissions in Tampa, FL
pros: Argosy University is extremely compliant to all rules and regulations. Students are treated with the upmost request and admiration. A lot of opportunities to advance your career and better yourself.
cons: Constant change. High turnover in VP and higher positions therefore because of the ever changing world of for profit education. Very little, if any, recognition or praise.

pros:
Work Environment - Great environment to work in as you can have fun while helping people better themselves with an education.

Advancement - Opportunity to grow within. 

Benefits - Tuition benefits - Better yourself while you help others do the same.

Transition to Non-Profit!!! Great opportunity for staff and our students.
cons: Have to put in some late nights to help students on the west coast - Flex time is available that helps balance this.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Chicago, IL
pros: Met some great people and the graduate level programs have fantastic instructors
cons: The Chicago campus is extremely corrupt, racist place to work. Management works for the advancement of themselves and the business and not the employees or the students. Following the EDMC $95.5million settlement things have just gotten worse.

pros: Great programs with great instructors and program chairs that actually care
cons: for profit side of things take over everything. Constantly told by management to get the numbers, they don't care about the student. While there are people who fight on behalf of the student, management has no problem throwing you under the bus if it helps them keep their job

job_title: Financial Aid Ifficer in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good co-workers and good benefits. Management is supportive. Excellent tuition benefits and employee discounts such as car discounts, phone service discounts, etc
cons: No advancement opportunities. Seemed like management liked to hire from outside than promote from within. Pay could be better, there were a coupleof yearsof pay freezes. Fast paced environment basedon achieving unrealistic numbers.

job_title: Director of Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Great culture - Team Environment - Having a purpose every day you come in - The Success stories of Staff & Students when they accomplish something when others told them they couldn't do it
cons: Technology for staff & students - It will get better soon

pros: Great potential after the buyout goes through.  Culture is improving but pay is stagnant.
cons: Not flexible at all for work hours.  Computers, printers, etc are old and maintained on a shoestring budget. Training is poor. Very secretive and non-inclusive culture.

pros: Great coworkers. Good pay for the work.
cons: I went through multiple transitions with the company and every new management was clueless. Poorly managed business- top management would constantly make decisions and cuts without a plan to successfully continue business and blame employees when numbers were not met. Also, kept important communications until the last minute- even with presidents of colleges and human resource managers.  Management doesn't care about serving students a quality education- just what can pad their wallets more.  Extreme case of nepotism in the home office.

review_title: Great Friendly and Professional... in the Short Run
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Schaumburg, IL
pros: At the very local level, the campus has really good people working there who are honest compassionate and caring.  It is a good starter job with great training, especially in sales.  Years later, I am still friends with people I worked with at Argosy... there is a bond.
cons:
Above the local level things get rough.  Decisions are repeatedly top down with little to no consideration of students, employees or implementation and are ironically often reversed.  Also, an acute fear of reprieval exists on the campus management level.  In one instance a PhD senior faculty member who was diagnosed with terminal cancer felt the need to keep it a secret until a week before she died.  She hid this because she was petrified that if she revealed her condition she would be fired.  Sadly, I agree.  Illinois is an at-will state and employees can and are fired for whatever reason.  One day this included the campus President, Director of Operations, Director of Human Resources, One of the IT guys and a worker from the library.  I mention this because job security and being fired is a consistantly and openly stated fear in the company, even among the best employees.

Additionally, there is little career growth on the campus level.  A person doesn't move up from a local campus level... or it is very very difficult and yet to be demonstrated in my four years of working there.  The hours and pressure to get admissions can be intense and at the local campus level it is a very high context environment.  In other words, you are very aware of your place and rank when things get tense.  

When looking for other jobs, I have been told that the for-profit education sector's former employees are judged unfairly in interviews and it can become a vortex that keeps you in for-profit education (though I have never experienced that myself, nor have I known of anyone NOT getting hired because of their for-profit experience per se).

Finally, there is a lot of pressure with lawmakers and the gainful employment laws.  Massive lobbying has apparently taken the teeth out of the legislation, but there was a lot revealed when congress did those investigations.  As a result, morale is rock bottom, management doesn't get it and this is why the stock is the lowest it has ever been. With the way things are, I would bet Argosy is being poised to be purchased.  I do not expect this company to survive in the long run.  All in all, it's a good starter career and I would advise not continuing one's employment there beyond 2 years.

review_title: The entire time I was there, it was frustrating and awful.
pros: They have a decent salary and benefits. They also really took the time to train you on most of the job requirements. Also, the Sarasota campus did occasional events and potlucks. And when I left, the admissions team was great. My coworkers really supported each other and worked to help each other out. Most importantly, there was no "cutthroat" atmosphere in admissions...it was frowned upon to "steal" students from another admissions rep. This made it a much more collaborative environment.
cons: There are plenty. I had a few major frustrations. One being the challenge of getting students. You never technically do any cold calling, but there are so many leads that are provided that were mistakenly made. The database of leads was ridiculous. They were having us call leads that were 5 years old (yes, you read that right). That's how bad the business was. There was such a lack of new leads that we were having to go that far back. And of course, it would be your funeral if you tried to bring up the fact that the leads were crap. You'd be spoonfed a statement like "there's no such thing as a bad lead." Absolute garbage. The other major frustration I had was the restructuring of the company. They changed the management of regions and we had a new regional manager type (I forget the actual title), who was in charge of a few of the Argosy locations. This person was awful. They used intimidation and they had absolutely no people skills at all. This person didn't like the approach of one of the admissions reps, so they sat at the AR's desk for hours one day. They also talked down to others, which was not ok. My other issue was with the employee review process. There are several competencies, like professionalism, product knowledge, student focus, and a few others. Now say that you don't hit your expected numbers. They will start to change your different competencies from "exceeds" or "meets expectations" to "below expectations." It's frustrating to be completely professional at all times and representing the company well, but as soon as you're not hitting your numbers, they might say "well, if you're not getting students, then you must not be professional." But since they can't actually fire you for not hitting your numbers, then this is how they have to do it I suppose. Ridiculous.

pros: In my experience the pay was good, my office was in a great location, I was given a good amount of vacation time, and they offer tuition reimbursement.
cons:
Monotonous- In my second interview which was an in-person interview, I asked what I would be doing on a typical day at Argosy, I was lead to believe that every day was different and exciting. NOT THE CASE every single miserable day I would sit at my desk, with my headset on making phone calls for 8.5 hours or I was in a training session about making phone calls. Nothing exciting about it in the slightest. 

Lack of job security- In my location, new groups of Success Advisors were being hired every single month, but the pool of students who were willing and able to go to school wasn't getting any bigger. This put a lot of pressure on SAs to stay on top of their game because it was very obvious that everyone was replaceable, layoffs were constant. 

Sales- I took this position because I was excited to help students, unfortunately, that's a very tiny part of this job. Management is OBSESSED with numbers! I spent most of my day calling through a random pool of numbers and reading a script. Hardly anyone you speak to is actually interested in school, that doesn't matter to management, though. You are supposed to get these people into a program whether they're interested or not. Many times while talking to a potential student I would come to the realization that school wasn't the best option for them financially, that doesn't matter to management either because they think nothing of having a student take out all sorts of loans. Many times I would gracefully end the call without signing them up for school, because in good conscience I just couldn't. This would always get me in trouble as all of the calls are recorded and letting someone go without getting them enrolled is a big no no. 

Lack of Recognition- No matter what you do it's never enough at this place. You can reach all your goals or even surpass them but management will always be there to remind you that you should be doing more. 

Work Life Balance- During the interview process, it was made to seem as if the position had a set schedule and if you were willing and able to stay late or come in on weekends to "help" students you were more than welcome to. However, once I was in the position I was constantly pressured to stay after normal business hours and come in on weekends. I was made to feel like the work I accomplished during my 8.5 hour day meant nothing if I wasn't staying late. It didn't matter that I had children to pick up from daycare at the end of the day. I did come in one Saturday and learned that by "helping" students they meant making more obnoxious telemarketing calls to uninterested people.

Management- I believe that many of the SAs care about the well being of the students but management couldn't care less. Argosy is a for-profit company and they see each new enrollment as a big check and each employee as totally disposable.

review_title: I wish I had read reviews before naively believing what I was sold about this position and company
job_title: Assistant Director of Admission in Sarasota, FL
pros: When I was employed you were provided a fair salary plus free education. I intended to receive my graduate degree while working for them but there was no way it was worth it
cons:
The position title “assistant director of admissions” was completely misleading. After arriving I learned that’s what all of the 10 or so admissions sales reps were called.

We had a very strict set script we had to read to every potential student, forcing them to stay on the phone with us for over an hour for an “interview”.  

High pressure to enroll everyone possible regardless of their qualifications or financial situation with totally unreasonable quotas. 

No regard for students. 

Job security constantly threatened. 

We were pushed to encourage everyone to use federal financial aid/loans if they couldn’t afford the over priced tuition, even if it wasn’t a good fit

All they cared about were enrollment quotas. 

Every phone call was recorded then analyzed with management. Condescending and constant micro managing from directors. 

This was the worst job I’ve ever had. I expected to love helping people further their education but this was a high pressure, greed driven operation. 

When I had something personal come up, I asked for short term personal leave so I could travel to see family out of state. My director approved the leave, so I left. Then the day after I left she changed her mind and threatened me that if I didn’t return to work that day I would no longer have a job. 

Although I qualified for unemployment and definitely some legal action based on this, I decided to not go back and just move on to find a healthier job environment. 

They couldn’t keep a campus president on staff. High turn over.

review_title: Great team of staff, innovative Campus President
pros: One of the most successful Argosy campuses, the Hawaii location offers a solid work environment with great colleagues.
cons: Parent company, EDMC, is very financially shaky right now, so things do change and could change at any time.

pros: I had amazing co workers.
cons: The company is crumbling. I witnessed three lay offs in one year. There was no room for advancement. Huge turnover. The departments cannot co-exist and function in a cohesive way. Everything is purely numbers based, which is not the way education should be.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great benefits and opportunity to continue your education as well as your family.
cons: They sell you on the opportunity to advance, but there isn't. Your stuck in a cublicle to do the same thing everyday until you quit or get fired.

job_title: Director Finance and Administration in Pittsburg, CA
pros: It is a great work environment.  Great staff and faculty. Great interaction with students and assist in their progress to degree completion.
cons: I think the corporation doesn't look at the quality of the education and is solely driven by historical data which with the current climate of proprietary schools needs to change its approach to recruiting and retaining students.

pros: The air conditioning worked well. There were benefits. And coffee. Sometimes people brought snacks. Not a lot I liked about this place, honeslty.
cons: Pressured to sign people up for classes who are unlikely to succeed. Phones were on auto-dial. Graudation rate was very low, and yet sales pressure very high. I felt like I was making the world a worse place.

review_title: Was not a challenging work environment, and supervisors were not experienced enough.
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Helping students further their education, and being able to follow up with them along their program is rewarding.
cons: Supervisor and President of this location are not supportive of the staff members, and do not help them improve upon their skills, or grow within the company.

pros: I loved working there.  My supervisors were all amazing. The training was very helpful. I was able to help a lot of people onto their educational and career goals there.
cons: There were none for me.  I just lived far away so my commute was long.

review_title: Very professional faculty and great degree offerings.
pros: Argosy University offers a wonderful educational focus with their degree offerings.
cons: Difficult to attract students wanting more of a ground campus experience.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Pros: Free education, great students (sometimes)
cons: Horrible leadership, it was very immature and would pit employees against each other and make people lie to HR to get employees they disliked fired. They enrolled anyone with an SSN. once had a homeless student harass me and the staff, yet they couldn't kick him out until after he applied because they wanted his money. Oh and the benefits are horrible.

pros: Helping people reach their potential is the most rewarding.
cons: It is difficult for working people to keep to their programs because life introduce scheduling challenges.

review_title: Very Talented co-workers who care and go the extra mile.  Very poor leadership!
pros: Discount on tuition, pretty good benefits.  Very nice co-workers.
cons: Leadership has unrealistic expectations.  No Marketing Strategy for the company.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admission in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Great opportunity for individual develop and build relationship with clientele.
cons: Customer base can be unreliable, many unknown variables can impede personal success. Numerous upper management turnover operating in heard it through the grapevine communication pattern.

pros: Wonderful coworkers, great benefits, unbelievable atmosphere, very fast paced exciting environment that encourages employees improve processes and procedures, work life balance is a priority and employees are given a lot of paid time off
cons: Schedule can be tough due to the later hours

pros: Great Admissions and Faculty.  The Financial Aid is very helpful.  They all have the interest of the student in mind.
cons: Bad location for parking but at least they validate in the garage . Campus is split into two buildings which makes it less convenient.

pros: Dedicated hard-working student support staff.
cons: No opportunity to advance.  Plagued with layoffs and cutbacks.  Poor management from the top down.  Non-existent communication between departments.

pros: On one hand the most of the Argosy staff were great, they were easy to talk and always willing to help.
cons: There were a few people in key positions that could NOT care less about Argosy employees or students; at times this made the situation unbearable.

review_title: Unethical telemarketing to disinterested, unqualified & incapable
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Tampa, FL
pros: Good fit if you are unethical, immoral and driven by selling "impulse buys" to unqualified candidates.
cons: Extreme micromanagement; chained to your phone telemarketing hundreds of calls per day to disinterested, unqualified, some even homeless, or deeply in debt  individuals to sell them on enrolling in overpriced, substandard degree programs which most will never  complete  and be left financially ruined  with dismal job prospects.

pros: Great people in the company at a ground level. Students and Health Science programs are very good.
cons: Very top heavy company. Focusing on getting students to only take online courses, when students are adamantly against this. Only look at the money side of things, not the students.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Co-workers were all great, benefits were good at the start but have since declined
cons: Management don't seem to understand general business concepts, 401k was eliminated, upper level leadership expects unrealistic performance in an industry that is so highly regulated

pros: pay for school (tuition- not fees)
cons: The company doesn't support growth and keeps the employees in the dark about everything.  The rules are changed every day on how to recruit students.  There is no appreciation and it has just become a toxic environment.

job_title: Student Worker in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Good work environment. Many opportunities to learn and grow if you want to work in the for profit education system. Very flexible schedule and excellent co workers as well as company culture.
cons: Having a hard time thinking of any other than the commute.

job_title: Graduate Academic Counselor in Chandler, AZ
pros: They will give you a chance and you can take advantage of free undergrad tuition.
cons: They did not understand how or what it takes to keep this company standing.  No one knows what their economic value to the company was. They would have quarterly desk moves to try and "Shake things up". It never worked.

review_title: Great undergraduate and graduate-level programs.  Awful, greedy owners
pros: Accredited Masters and Doctoral programs.  Awesome faculty and staff.
cons: Dream Center Educational Holdings, the most recent owners, gave up on the school and pocketed money with the help of the current Ms. DeVoss and others at the Department of Education.  The school is now closed.  Stay away from WOZU as it is owned by DCEH.

pros: The pros of this school is learning at your own paste, help when you need it, convenient for people with other things to do, like work or hobbies!
cons: I don't have any down sides for this company.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Phoenix, AZ
pros: Free coffee, regulated office temperature.
cons: This place is a sweatshop. Your phone is on autodial all day while managers listen to your calls to make sure you don't go off script. The school is not a credible university. The graduation rate is very low and the student debt load is very high. High pressure sales environment masquerading as admission counseling.

pros: You don't work on commissions so the stress of that is taken out of the picture in a sales roles, excellent management willing to work with you and wants to see you succeed
cons: Not a lot of room for growth

pros: Great faculty and educational programs that really prepared our students well for entering the work force.
cons: For profit status of the University and lack of an endowment makes for tough finances in the current political climate.

review_title: This job is a joke!  Get out while you can. Terrible Management
pros:
Loved my Co-Workers 
Pay & Benefits
cons:
Where to begin...
no job security
no opportunity for advancement
not what originally applied for. Management is VERY misleading
Extremely high turnover
Call Center type environment- exp to make 200 calls per day
Constant change of policy and procedure
Heavy Micro Managing. 
List goes on and on......

job_title: Admissions Representative in Des Plaines, IL
pros: Fun staff, supportive and at times express care for students and employees.  Good benefits.
cons: Very numbers driven operation.  Nothing unethical however they wanted everyone to apply and just see what happens for the student.

review_title: Wonderful colleagues, company was mismanaged by new owners
pros: The staff, faculty, students, and administration were outstanding to work with.
cons: Financial mismanagement by new owners led company to close, with the exception of a couple of campuses that were bought and survived.

pros: Great communication between faculty and staff, everyone is friendly and helpful. Issues encountered there are often resolved quickly and effectively.
cons: Timing plays a huge role in planning as some employees work less standard hours.

pros: Faculty and Staff are responsive and helpful. Students are motivated and hard working. Argosy is definitely a supportive community. Class schedules are flexible with various learning styles.
cons: Sometimes students are registered to the wrong class.

review_title: Great people and programs, but in financial trouble
pros: Great environment, great people. Twin Cities has great Health Science programs.
cons: Overhead company, for-profit EDMC, sold Argosy to non-profit DCEH while in serious financial trouble. Now in a Federal Receivership.

pros: Argosy provided my start/introduction to teaching on a collegiate level.  I've worked for the university for nearly 7 years.
cons: Advancement from an adjunct into another role is not easy.

job_title: Campus IT Analyst in Honolulu, HI
pros: You can request for a convenient work schedule.
cons: The financial status of the University dictates how long employees could stay working here (no long term job stability).

pros: Meet and assist lots of great students. Ditto for co-workers.
cons: The commute from Richmond to Alameda.

pros: Great co-workers!  Makes the job more enjoyable and the days go by faster.  Made some really good friends from my time working for the company.
cons: No room for advancement.  Low wages.

job_title: Adjunct Instructor in New Orleans, LA
pros: Fair compensation for adjuncts, good communication in the departments through monthly meetings
cons: Multiple discussions in week 1 and mandatory calls to students, a very lax late policy for students to submit work

pros: Classes are prepared and uniform across all  campus locations.
cons: New program, has some management glitches that need to be ironed out.

pros: Relaxed work environment with autonomy within my specific department.
cons: No job security towards the end.

pros: They should have notified employees that they were going to let everyone go and close the University.
cons: Nothing to talk about anymore.  They are out of business.

pros: Great pay, great training, and free school
cons:
Uncertain future 
total transition on the horizon
 unrealistic goals

pros: Excellent supervisor and flexible schedule.
cons: Pay could be better and more in line with industry standards.

pros: The best people to work with.
cons: Poor management.  Lack of communication.  Misleading information.

job_title: Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Qualified Teachers/ Staff,  Collaborative effort at the campus
cons: Internal politics.  Senior management did not give clear expectations

pros: online position - flexible schedule based on the ability to work form home on pretty much any location within the U.S.
cons: For-profit institution, on call 24/7 even weekends, no down time, vacation limited and only if approved, treat employees very poorly, disrespectfully and do not promote professional development or research activities

pros: I have learned new things
cons: They should make provision to give break time for part time workers.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Farmers Branch, TX
pros: Working with students was the best part of it.

job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Denver, CO
pros: Wonderful people to work with.

job_title: Assistant Director Graduate Admissions in Pittsburgh, PA
pros: Help students to be successful.

pros: Teaching background includes HR, Management and English courses.  Coaching and mentoring students to success is perfect time spent!  I love teaching.
cons: None.  Argosy University give support to the faculty in many ways.  The president, staff and Chairs for each department are fully engaged in helping students and faculty.

pros: I love the diversity and the location.
cons: No cons. Argosy University is a great place to teach.

pros: Students were very bright and eager to learn.
